description.narrative: This project will enhance the Niue’s capacities to effectively create and manage its protected areas, focusing on the expansion of its Protected Areas estate on land and on its marine areas. (PPG)

title.narrative: Ridge to Reef in Niue PPG

description.narrative: The IRRF is UNDP’s results framework to monitor and report on its achievements against the Strategic Plan 2014-2017. UNDP publishes country level IRRF results that UNDP’s projects contributed to
Extent to which legal frameworks are in place for conservation, sustainable use, and access and benefit sharing of natural resources, biodiversity and ecosystems
Extent to which policy frameworks are in place for conservation, sustainable use, and access and benefit sharing of natural resources, biodiversity and ecosystems
Extent to which institutional frameworks are in place for conservation, sustainable use, and access and benefit sharing of natural resources, biodiversity and ecosystems
Extent to which capacities to implement national and local plans for Integrated Water Resources Management have improved
Extent to which capacities to protect and restore the health, productivity and resilience of oceans and marine ecosystems, have improved
Niue Ridge to Reef Preparatory Phase Grant (PPG) covers coordination, management and financial oversight of UNDP and management arrangement and prepare the project document.
capital of a political entity
Environment - policy, planning and administration
Full size Project document approved

comment.narrative: 2. Project document was approved by GEF on 4th April 2016

description.narrative: Application of Ridge to Reef Concept for Biodiversity Conservation and for the Enhancement of Ecosystem Services and Cultural Heritage in Niue_NIUE Ridge to Reef Full-Sized Project

title.narrative: Application to Ridge to Reef Concept for Biodiversity Conservation and for the Enhancement of Ecosystem Services and Cultural Heritage in Niue

description.narrative: Application of Ridge to Reef Concept for Biodiversity Conservation and for the Enhancement of Ecosystem Services and Cultural Heritage in Niue_FSP
capital of a political entity
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

Project Objective: 1. Incorporation of cultural and traditional values and approaches in natural resources protection and management 2. The freshwater lens safeguarded in the long term 3. Terrestrial and reef species are being utilized on a sustainable basis to an increasing number of community members
Outcome 1: 1.1 Extent of the protected estate in various forms and through different protective mechanisms 1.2 Efforts in place for the recovery of species at risk 1.3 Status of completion and adoption of management plans for various conservation areas
Outcome 2: 2.1 Promotion of R2R approach by Village Councils and Government departments 2.2 The extent to which biodiversity and natural resources are taken into account in central and local planning, management and daily life 2.3 Level of awareness, sensitivity and understanding of the value and vulnerability of natural resources

comment.narrative:
Project Objective: 1. Cultural values and constraints are reported as being eroded away 2. Freshwater lens at risk from agricultural chemicals, and septic tank effluent 3. Some reef species such as Tridacna sp., and Holothuria sp., have been reported as diminished. Peka, Lupe and Uga populations have declined; utilization rates to be established during the first year
Outcome 1: 1.1 Tapu areas are many but not all are known or acknowledged; Huvalu Forest Conservation Area (5,400 ha) and Namoui Marine Reserve (27.67 ha) are the only Protected Areas 1.2 Hega (blue-crowned lory) and the olive small-scaled skink are considered endangered; Uga and Peka are currently considered as threatened. Both are being harvested unsustainably. 1.3 Huvalu Conservation Area and Beveridge Reef – no Management Plan; Reefs covered somewhat by Coastal Management Plan
Outcome 2: 2.1 There is currently no comprehensive, holistic approach applied by Village Councils or Government Departments to natural resources management 2.2 Neither sector plans nor Village Development Plans can be said to have mainstreamed biodiversity considerations 2.3 There is a certain level of awareness but it is not deep. The baseline will be established through survey at the Inception Phase
1. Project document approval and signing 2. Project inception phase and workshop 3. Recruitment of PMU

1. Project document was signed on 4th April 2016 2. Interim project specialist recruited on 28th April 2016 and inception workshop was held 6 - 7 July 2016. Project equipment procured through UNDP 3. Project Procurement and Finance Officer recruited, Project Manager recruited in July 2016 also but resigned to take up another position. Replacement for PM recruited in Dec 2016

End of Project Targets: Project Objective: 1. Culturally significant species, habitats and methods of conservation are identified, recorded and being built upon 2. Biodegradable or certified organic agri- chemicals used exclusively; and at least 80% of septic tank effluent treated, such that risk of contamination of the freshwater lens controlled or removed 3. Access or utilization by communities for food and other uses increased by 25% but on a sustainable basis
Outcome 1: 1.1 Additional 2550 ha of terrestrial ecosystems; additional 4500 ha of marine ecosystem; and, additional 200 ha of reef, protected by various instruments by the end of the project 1.2 Species Recovery Plans for Hega and the olive small-scaled skink formulated, adopted and being implemented; Species Management Plans for Uga and Peka formulated, adopted and being implemented. 1.3 Huvalu Conservation Area, Beveridge Reef MPA, Western Reef Conservation Area, and new Confluence Conservation Area, all with management plans adopted and being implemented
Outcome 2: 2.1 New Village Development Plans, and reviewed existing ones, showing an explicitly comprehensive (R2R) and integrated approach towards land, water and natural resource management. 2.2 Corporate Plans, Annual Work Plans and similar key documents, showing an explicitly comprehensive (R2R) and integrated approach towards land, water and natural resource management; together will collaboration across departmental boundaries. 2.3 Biodiversity considerations become an explicit element in policies, plans, strategies and similar instruments An improvement of 20-50% in awareness and understanding as measured by a repeat survey.

title.narrative: UN Joint Presence & Coordination in Niue

description.narrative: After a study conducted in 2015 about Joint Presence Offices (JPOs) in the Pacific. The UN system agreed to establish JPOs in the Cook Island & Niue to be led by UN Coordination Officers for 3 years (2016-2018).

document-link.url: https://info.undp.org/docs/pdc/Documents/NIU/UN JPO Cook Islands and Niue Prodoc with signed cover page.pdf

title.narrative: UN Joint Presence & Coordination in Niue

description.narrative: United Nations agreed to establish a Joint Presence Offices and placing UN Coordination officer in Niue, this will contribute to the UN development system leadership and coordination.
